segment.source: You can enable the built-in Administrator account during unattended installations by setting the setting to Administrator in the Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup component.
segment.target: You can enable the built-in Administrator account during unattended installations by setting the setting to Administrator in the Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup component.

segment.source: This will enable the built-in Administrator account, even if a password is not specified in the setting.
segment.target: This will enable the built-in Administrator account, even if a password is not specified in the setting.

segment.source: You can create an answer file by using Windows® System Image Manager (Windows SIM).

segment.source: Use the Local Users and Groups MMC (server versions only)
segment.target: Use the Local Users and Groups MMC (server versions only)

segment.source: Change the properties of the Administrator account by using the Local Users and Groups Microsoft Management Console (MMC).
segment.target: Change the properties of the Administrator account by using the Local Users and Groups Microsoft Management Console (MMC).

segment.source: Open MMC, and then select Local Users and Groups.
segment.target: Open MMC, and then select Local Users and Groups.

segment.source: Right-click the Administrator account, and then select Properties.
segment.target: Right-click the Administrator account, and then select Properties.

segment.source: The Administrator Properties window appears.
segment.target: The Administrator Properties window appears.

segment.source: On the General tab, clear the Account is Disabled check box.
segment.target: On the General tab, clear the Account is Disabled check box.

segment.source: Close MMC.
segment.target: Close MMC.

segment.source: Administrator access is now enabled.
segment.target: Administrator access is now enabled.

segment.source: Disabling the Built-in Administrator Account
segment.target: Disabling the Built-in Administrator Account

segment.source: For new installations, after the end user creates a user account in OOBE, the built-in Administrator account is disabled.
segment.target: For new installations, after the end user creates a user account in OOBE, the built-in Administrator account is disabled.

segment.source: For upgrade installations, the built-in Administrator account remains enabled when there is no other active local administrator on the computer, and when the computer is not joined to a domain.
segment.target: For upgrade installations, the built-in Administrator account remains enabled when there is no other active local administrator on the computer, and when the computer is not joined to a domain.

segment.source: Use either of the following methods to disable the built-in administrator account:
segment.target: Use either of the following methods to disable the built-in administrator account:

segment.source: Run the sysprep /generalize command
segment.target: Run the sysprep /generalize command

segment.source: When you run the sysprep /generalize command, the next time that the computer starts, the built-in Administrator account will be disabled.
segment.target: When you run the sysprep /generalize command, the next time that the computer starts, the built-in Administrator account will be disabled.

segment.source: Instructions
segment.target: Instructions

segment.source: When you run the sysprep /generalize command on Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2008 R2, the Sysprep tool resets the built-in Administrator account password.
segment.target: When you run the sysprep /generalize command on Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2008 R2, the Sysprep tool resets the built-in Administrator account password.

segment.source: The Sysprep tool only clears the built-in Administrator account’s password for server editions, not for client editions.
segment.target: The Sysprep tool only clears the built-in Administrator account’s password for server editions, not for client editions.

segment.source: The next time that the computer starts, Setup displays a prompt for a password.
segment.target: The next time that the computer starts, Setup displays a prompt for a password.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: In Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2008 R2, and Windows Server 2008, the default password policy requires a strong password for all user accounts.
segment.target: In Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2008 R2, and Windows Server 2008, the default password policy requires a strong password for all user accounts.

segment.source: To configure a weak password, you can use an answer file that includes the Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup setting.
segment.target: To configure a weak password, you can use an answer file that includes the Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup setting.

segment.source: You cannot configure a weak password, either manually or by using a script such as the net user command.
segment.target: You cannot configure a weak password, either manually or by using a script such as the net user command.
